climbs.name: Battling the Winds of Warm Winter
climbs.fa: Lucas Toron and Max Fisher, February 2016

content.description:
Pitch 1 - Climb a snow and ice gully to an opening below a steeper section of ice. WI 2, 30 meters
Pitch 2 - Move up over a 15 meter vertical section of ice to a lower angle ramp that leads to a small cave and belay. WI4+ 35 meters
Pitch 3 - Continue up and left climbing snow and ice through a narrow slot all the way to the top of the cliff. 65 meters, WI 3

About a 7 minute walk south of ETD. Impossible to miss if you have the photo. Look for a short gully that leads to steep ice.
A rack of screws.

climbs.name: Choss Factory
climbs.fa: Max Fisher and Fred Giroux, February, 2017

content.description:
Pitch 1 - Move right of ridge and up a series of vertical steps on good hooks to a ledge. 25 m M5
Pitch 2 - Traverse right on rock (M4) to get to thin ice gully. Take this to the top.

This will be the first route encountered after you round the point and the cliff appears on your left. 
A small rack of screws, a few pins and maybe some nuts. Don't expect to find much gear in this rock.

Scrambled up the third class ridge to the base of a 5th class rocky buttress (see photo). P1 - Rope up and climb to top, to a grassy ledge. We build an anchor by slinging two boulders. M3R 60 m (Pitons and slings). Scramble down right to the start of the ice in gully. We were able to build a small anchor with pitons and cams. P2 - Climb thin ice up a tight gully, to a cave WI 3+ 35 m. P3 - From the cave, climb out left to the top WI 5+ 40 m. 



Walk past Enter the Dragon and Early Bird.

To the right of Early Bird, on the other side of the buttress, you will see a series of ice flows.

Civil Disobedience is the left most flow.

Small rack, ice screws and don’t forget pins!

climbs.name: Early Bird Gets the Worm
climbs.fa: Luc Gallant and Max Fisher, January, 2016

content.description:
If you look right of the Enter the Dragon gully you will see a wall of ice high on the cliff. This is the route. Scramble up to the base of the ice and belay. Climb steep ice with several nice ledges to rest. 

Right of ETD.
A rack of screws.

climbs.name: Enter the Dragon
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Max Fisher and Matthew Peck, January 2014

content.description:
Striking featured, gully capped with a spectacular roof pitch near the top. A very adventurous climb. Very committing in less than ideal conditions. 

This is the second established line you will encounter once you enter the zone following the approach along the coast. Pretty hard to miss. 
A rack of screws, maybe a few pins or some small nuts.

climbs.name: Keep on Blowing
climbs.fa: Max Fisher and Luc Gallant, December 2013

content.description:
Nice easy climbing right off the beach. Fun line. 

This route is just right of There She Blows. Wide curtain that reaches the beach. 
A rack of screws.

climbs.name: The Reckoning
climbs.fa: Max Fisher and Lucas Toron, January, 2017

content.description:
Pitch 1 - Climb a thin pillar to a low angled ramp. WI4+  50 meters
Pitch 2 - Continue up climbing over some incredibly cool ice umbrellas near the top. WI3+ 40 meters.

Located approximately 100 meters south of Sweet Chimney of Love. 
A rack of screws.

climbs.name: Redemption
climbs.fa: Luc Gallant, Michel Martin and Marty Levesque

content.description:
Pitch 1 - Climb a steep snow gully that leads up and right for 30 meters to a steep pillar of ice. Climb the 20 meter pillar and belay off rock gear on the left hand side. WI4+ 60 meters
Pitch 2 - Continue up the gully at first on snow then ice which will steepen. Stop and belay off ice screws in a cave below a skinny, vertical pillar. WI4+ M4 30 meters
PItch 3 - Step up on an ice mushroom to reach the pillar. Climb the pillar and or stem your way up the narrow chimney for about 25 meters where you will reach a snow gully. Climb the snow gully to the top of the cliff and belay off small trees. WI5+ M4 55 meters

This is the next major featured gully south of ETD approximately 200 meters away. 
A rack of screws, small rock rack and a few pins.
Max Fisher and Luc Gallant made the first attempt on this in 2017 climbing all the way to the crux 3 pitch. They were thwarted by a massive ice umbrella that proved impossible to climb through or around. In December of 2018 Max and Luc returned with Michel Martin to give it another go. They climbed almost half of the route before deciding to bail due to poor ice conditions. On the descent, very near the bottom Michel took a short fall while trying to retrieve the rope. He unfortunately broke his foot/ankle quite badly when he hit the ground. Despite the broken foot but with the help of Max and Luc, Michel was able to get off the beach and back to the car just in time as the tide was fast approaching. Michel needed two surgeries and 6 months to recover from his injury but was determined to climb again. A little more than 13 months from the day of the accident Michel returned with Luc and Marty Levesque to try once again to climb this line. This time they were successful and were happy to find good ice, challenging climbing and a route worth the effort. Congrats to Michel on his triumphant return.

climbs.name: Sweet Chimney of Love
climbs.fa: Max Fisher and Greg Hughes, December 2013

content.description:
Pitch 1 - Thin scratchy climbing leads to a low angle ramp. WI3+ 50 meters. 
Pitch 2 - Continue up on ice through the gully as it narrows to a chimney. Climb the chimney to the top navigating an ice umbrella exit. M5 60 meters.

Huge obvious chimney from the beach. Just right of Winds of Warm Winter. Very easy to find. 
A rack of screws, maybe some pins.

climbs.name: There She Blows
climbs.fa: Luc Gallant and Max Fisher, January, 2016

content.description:
Narrow flow of ice that widens and eases off the higher you get. 

 Found 300 meters north of the lighthouse point. Look for a good ice flow that reaches the beach.
A rack of screws.

Rich in history, this unique area is home to some of the steepest, longest ice routes in the province. All of the routes are found along the coast on a finger of land that juts out into the Bay of Fundy. The bay holds has some of the highest tides in the world so access to the beach and the base of the routes can be complicated. Plan your climbing here based on the low tide time. A low tide time of between 11 am and 1 pm is best. Most of the development has occurred on the west side of the land feature that makes up Cap d'Or. Here you will find routes looking very much like alpine climbs in the rockies. This section faces mostly southwest so you will be mostly in the sun in the afternoon hours. This combined with a fickle marine climate make the climbing season here relatively short. Generally it lasts from late December to early February in a good year.
